doc.field: Randolph and Codwise families property dispute papers
Randolph and Codwise families property dispute papers

Accounts, correspondence, and property documents spanning the period 1849 to 1896 and relating to the property dispute between the Codwise and Randolph families. Materials mostly derive from the two families' dealings with the law firm Storrs and Sedgwick and the realtors who managed the property in question.

Accounts, correspondence, and property documents spanning the period 1849 to 1896 and relating to the property dispute between the Codwise and Randolph families. Materials mostly derive from the two families' dealings with the law firm Storrs and Sedgwick and the realtors who managed the property in question.

This collection contains accounts, correspondence, and property documents spanning the period 1849 to 1896 and relating to the property dispute between the Codwise and Randolph families. Materials mostly derive from the two families' dealings with the law firm Storrs and Sedgwick and the realtors who managed the property in question.

Several parcels of land lying within the triangle formed by Flatbush Avenue and Nevins and Livingston Streets in Brooklyn were the subject of an ownership dispute between the Codwise and Randolph families from 1877 to 1886, due to the separation of Charles F. Codwise and his wife, Martha Jane Randolph. The New York City-based law firm of Storrs and Sedgwick was also involved in the dispute.
Source and date of acquisition unknown. Formally accessioned in 1977.
